repnme.cdata!: Thailand - Public Sector Reform Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Lessons of experience drawn
            from the project implementation follow. The program
            structure of the project was appropriate, though the
            leverage from financing was limited, explained through the
            loan allocation to budget support - for institutional
            reforms as mandated by the Constitution, and counterpart
            assistance in policy reform - which emphasized flexibility,
            and sustained momentum for the reform process. Indeed,
            despite the Government's diminished financing needs as
            economic recovery strengthened, budget support, not only
            reinforced the management of the reform process, but allowed
            progressive agencies to in turn, promote competition, and
            reform. It is worth mentioning that, the intensive technical
            assistance in designing the reform program, succeeded (in
            part) because of the comprehensive, preparatory work of
            diagnostic studies, financed by the Economic Management
            Assistance Loan. However, the overly ambitious integration
            of sectoral reform plans - in health, education, and
            commerce - as originally designed, was hindered by the
            magnitude for imminent institutional, procedural, and
            cultural changes, which with proper incentives for
            performance management, may effectively integrate into the
            overall public sector reform, provided an enhanced
            monitoring from the Government, and civil society.

repnme.cdata!: Thailand - Public Sector Reform Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Reform Loan will
            support the reform program in Thailand, and, improve its
            public sector management through: 1) the implementation of
            performance-based budgeting for line ministries; thus,
            central agencies' capacity will be strengthened to
            review and evaluate sector policies and performance, and,
            fiscal transparency will be improved; 2) the restructure of
            service delivery, will align organizational structures of
            line ministries with new functional objectives, and, staff
            profiles, will be matched with new requirements for civil
            service. This restructure will in turn contain costs. Human
            resources management systems will be developed, to achieve
            modern civil service performances, and, a cross-governmental
            senior cadre, to lead the renewal process will be
            instituted, along with regulatory frameworks for autonomous
            public organizations; 3) an improved accountability and
            transparency, will strengthen revenue management, for better
            taxpayer compliance practices, and collection enforcement,
            with appropriate business and information technology
            priorities. Decentralization will provide adequate
            expenditure functions, enhancing local revenues/resources.
            Institutional accountability will be increased, and, public
            access to information and promotion will be enhanced.
            Nonetheless, insufficient inter-agency coordination, and,
            lack of political commitment to reform, may present risks.
